description: Borrowed from French échelon (“rung; echelon”), from échelle (“ladder”) + -on (“suffix forming diminutives”). Échelle is derived from Latin scāla (“ladder”), from scandō (“to ascend, climb”), from Proto-Indo-European *skend- (“to jump”).

entries.meaning: (linear algebra) Of a matrix: having undergone Gaussian elimination with the result that the leading coefficient or pivot (that is, the first nonzero number from the left) of a nonzero row is to the right of the pivot of the row above it, giving rise to a stepped appearance in the matrix.
A level or rank in an organization, profession, or society.
(cycling) A line of riders seeking maximum drafting in a crosswind, resulting in a diagonal line across the road.
(military) A formation of troops, ships, etc., in diagonal parallel rows. [from late 18th c.]

verbs.description: echelon (third-person singular simple present echelons, present participle echeloning, simple past and past participle echeloned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, military) To form troops into an echelon.
